text: When you drop an apple, we know that the
earth pulls on the apple and makes it
fall. We call this the force of gravity.
But the big question is, does the apple
also put a force on the earth? Let's
find out. Let's quickly recap. What
exactly is a force? Well, remember that
force is just a push or a pull. But what
exactly is needed for an object to
experience a push or a pull? The answer
is some kind of an interaction. For
example, when you hit a ball using your
bat, the bat is in contact with the ball
and it pushes the ball. It exerts a
force on the ball. We call this the
contact forces. Here, the bat is
interacting with the ball. But you don't
always need a contact. For example, if
you consider the force that the earth is
putting on the apple, for example, and
making it fall, look, there is no
contact over here. That's why these are
called non-cont forces. But there's
still an interaction. And the key thing
is that you need two objects. Um, an
apple cannot put a force on itself. You
need for example an earth to exert a
force on the apple. Similarly, a ball
for example cannot put a force on
itself. In this particular example, we
need a bat to push on it to exert a
force on it. So look, the forces arise
from interactions between two objects or
two particles you can say. But the big
question is this. When the bat interacts
with the ball, it exerts a force on the
ball. But does the bat experience a
force as well? Let's see. And to think
about this intuitively, imagine you're
not hitting a baseball. Imagine you're
hitting a bowling ball. I know it sounds
it sounds weird, but just think about
it. You take a bat and you try to whack
that bowling ball. You put a force on
that bowling ball. What's going to
happen? Oh, you can feel it in your
bones. That bat is either going to break
or it's going to fly backwards, isn't
it? So just from that intuitive feeling,
you can see that there must be a force
acting on the bat as well. And that
force will be backwards. So yes indeed,
there is a force acting on that bat. So
what you notice is that when the bat
puts a force on the ball, the ball puts
a force back on the bat. But how big is
this force? Well, let's think about it.
If you were to put a small force on that
ball, if you were to gently tap that
ball with a very tiny force, then you
wouldn't expect your bat to break. You
would expect a tiny force back on your
bat, isn't it? But if you put a giant
force on that ball, if you try to whack
it, then there's a very good chance that
bat is going to fly off or the bat is
going to break. So this means and we've
done careful experiments to arrive at
this conclusion. But this means that
when a bat puts a force on the ball, the
ball puts an equal but look opposite
force back on the bat. And this is true
in general for all forces. For example,
imagine you and your friend are skating
and you push your friend to the left.
What's going to happen? Well, surely
your friend is going to start moving
this way, but you will also get pushed
backwards, which means your friend will
also end up pushing on you and the force
lasts as long as there is contact. The
moment the contact is lost, the force is
gone. So this is always true and we give
a name to this. We call it the Newton's
third law. So in general we could say
when an object A puts a force on object
B, object P puts an equal and opposite
force back on object A. For example, if
the bat puts a force on B uh on the
ball, sorry, the ball puts an equal and
opposite force back on the bat.
Similarly, when this girl puts a force
on this boy, the boy puts an equal and
opposite force back on the girl. And by
the way, you're completely free to
choose which one is your A and which one
is your B. It doesn't matter. The force
only lasts as long as there's
interaction. Over here, the interaction
only exists when there's a contact. So
when the contact is gone, the force
disappears. And since this is true for
all forces, we can now answer our
original question. The Earth is putting
a force on the apple pulling it down. So
according to Newton's third law, the
apple must also put an equal and
opposite force back on the Earth. Which
means the apple is also pulling back on
the Earth with the exact same force.
That is not intuitive at all. I mean,
think about it. This apple is so tiny
and it has such a small mass compared to
the Earth and yet they exert exactly
equal but opposite forces on each other,
which is pretty awesome if you think
about it. So, according to Newton's
third law, forces will always always
come in pairs. But that raises another
big question. If forces always come in
pairs and they're always equal and
opposite to each other, shouldn't they
cancel out? Why don't they cancel out?
Well, because they are always acting on
different objects. For example, over
here, one force is acting on the apple.
The other force is acting on Earth.
Similarly, if you go back to our
previous example, look, one force is
acting on the ball, the other force is
being exerted on the bat. One force is
acting on the girl, the other force is
acting on the on the boy over here. So,
these pairs of forces are always acting
on different objects or on on different
particles. So they can never cancel out.
Remember when you're determining whether
forces are balanced or not, you're
talking about forces acting on one
single particle or one single object.
All right. Finally, the cool thing about
Newton's third law is if you know one of
the forces and you want to identify the
other force pair, then just switch the
words around. For example, a fish uses
its tail to put a backward force on the
water. Therefore, according to Newton's
third law, the water at the same time
puts a forward force on the fish.
Consider jumping. When you're jumping,
you put a downward force on the ground.
Well, according to the third law, at the
same time, the ground puts an upward
force back on you. And if you consider
the example of an apple or a ball
falling down, for example, the earth
pulls on the apple, pushes a downward
force, exerts a downward force on the
apple. According to Newton law, the
apple exerts an upward force on the
earth. So long story short, forces arise
due to interactions. Some of these
interactions will require contact,
others, like gravity for example, don't.
But you always have two particles or two
objects interacting with each other. And
as a result, forces always come in
pairs. These forces are always equal and
opposite, but because they're acting on
different objects, they will never
cancel out.
